Find Optimal Cut-off Based on Strength Patterns

Source: R/cutoff_sensitivity_strength.R
find_optimal_cutoff.Rd

Identifies the optimal cut-off value using various criteria based on strength metrics and network structure. The cut-off parameter determines which edges are included in the MONECA network by thresholding relative risk values. This function provides multiple strategies for selecting an optimal cut-off that balances network sparsity, clustering quality, and interpretability.

Usage

find_optimal_cutoff(
  mx,
  criterion = "elbow",
  cutoff_range = NULL,
  n_bootstrap = 30,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

mx

Mobility matrix with marginals (last row and column contain totals)

criterion

Optimization criterion to use. One of:

"elbow"

Finds the "elbow" point in the strength ratio curve using the point of maximum curvature. This identifies where adding more edges provides diminishing returns in network strength concentration. Best for: Automatic, data-driven cutoff selection without prior assumptions. Good for: Finding a natural break point in network density where strong ties are separated from weak ties. Trade-off: May not optimize for specific network properties like modularity or stability.

"stability"

Evaluates clustering stability using bootstrap resampling of the mobility matrix. Finds the cutoff where segment assignments are most consistent across resampled data, measured by coefficient of variation in node strengths. Best for: Ensuring robust, reproducible clustering results. Good for: Applications where stability and reliability are more important than optimizing other metrics. Trade-off: Computationally expensive (uses n_bootstrap samples, default 30) and may favor more connected networks.

"balance"

Balances edge retention with strength concentration by maximizing the product: $$score = edge\_retention \times strength\_ratio$$ This creates a trade-off between preserving network structure (many edges) and focusing on strong ties (high strength ratio). Best for: General-purpose clustering when you want neither too sparse nor too dense networks. Good for: Preserving interpretable network structure while maintaining focus on meaningful connections. Trade-off: May produce intermediate solutions that don't excel at any single metric.

"modularity"

Maximizes network modularity using fast greedy community detection. Modularity measures how well the network separates into distinct communities. Higher modularity indicates stronger within-group connections and weaker between-group connections. Best for: Identifying well-defined, non-overlapping social groups or mobility classes. Good for: Sociological research focused on community structure and social stratification. Trade-off: May favor sparser networks and can produce resolution limit issues in large networks.

"information"

Minimizes information loss while reducing network complexity by maximizing: $$efficiency = strength\_retention / edge\_retention$$ This criterion keeps the most important connections (high strength) while maximally simplifying the network (few edges). Best for: Creating parsimonious network representations with maximum explanatory power. Good for: Visualization and interpretation where network clarity is important. Trade-off: May produce very sparse networks that lose nuanced structural information.

cutoff_range

Numeric vector of cut-off values to test. If NULL (default), automatically determined from the relative risk distribution (5th to 95th percentile range)

n_bootstrap

Integer. Number of bootstrap samples for stability criterion. Higher values provide more reliable stability estimates but increase computation time. Default is 30, which provides reasonable balance between accuracy and speed

verbose

Logical. Whether to show progress messages and sensitivity analysis details. Default is TRUE

Value

A list of class "optimal_cutoff" containing:

optimal_cutoff

Numeric. The recommended cut-off value based on the specified criterion

criterion

Character. The criterion used for optimization

metrics

Data frame row. Network metrics at the optimal cut-off, including n_edges, mean_strength, strength_ratio, modularity, n_components, and clustering_coefficient

sensitivity_analysis

Data frame. Complete sensitivity analysis across all tested cut-off values, useful for plotting and further analysis

explanation

Character. Human-readable explanation of why this cut-off was selected, including key metric values

Details

Cut-off Selection in MONECA

The cut-off parameter is central to MONECA clustering as it determines which relative risk values create edges in the mobility network. Higher cut-offs produce sparser networks focusing on the strongest mobility ties, while lower cut-offs include weaker connections and produce denser networks.

Choosing an appropriate cut-off affects:

  • Network density and interpretability

  • Number and size of detected clusters

  • Stability of cluster assignments

  • Balance between within-cluster and between-cluster mobility

Recommended Workflow

  1. Start with criterion = "elbow" for an automatic, data-driven baseline cut-off

  2. Run sensitivity analysis to visualize how different cut-offs affect network properties

  3. If stability is critical (e.g., for longitudinal comparisons), use criterion = "stability"

  4. If identifying distinct communities is the goal, use criterion = "modularity"

  5. Compare results from multiple criteria to assess robustness

  6. Visualize the resulting networks using plot_cutoff_analysis() or plot_moneca_ggraph()

Computational Considerations

  • Fast criteria: "elbow", "balance", "modularity", "information" (seconds for typical datasets)

  • Slow criteria: "stability" (minutes for n_bootstrap=30, scales linearly with n_bootstrap and quadratically with matrix size)

  • For large matrices (>50 classes), consider reducing n_bootstrap or using a coarser cutoff_range

  • All criteria benefit from narrower cutoff_range if you have prior knowledge about appropriate values

See also

cutoff_sensitivity_analysis for detailed sensitivity analysis, evaluate_cutoff_strength for evaluating a single cut-off value, plot_cutoff_analysis for visualizing sensitivity curves, moneca for running the main clustering algorithm with the optimal cut-off

Examples

# Generate synthetic mobility data
data <- generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 5, seed = 123)

# 1. Find optimal cut-off using different criteria
optimal_elbow <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "elbow", verbose = FALSE)
optimal_balance <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "balance", verbose = FALSE)
optimal_mod <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "modularity", verbose = FALSE)

# Compare results
print(optimal_elbow)
#> Optimal Cut-off Analysis
#> ========================
#> Optimal cut-off value: 1.382 
#> Criterion used: elbow 
#> Explanation: Elbow point: Retains 44.4% of edges while maintaining 71.7% strength concentration 
#> 
#> Metrics at optimal point:
#>   n_edges: 4.000
#>   mean_strength: 2.962
#>   strength_ratio: 0.717
#>   modularity: 0.221
#>   n_components: 1.000
print(optimal_balance)
#> Optimal Cut-off Analysis
#> ========================
#> Optimal cut-off value: 0.219 
#> Criterion used: balance 
#> Explanation: Balanced trade-off: 100.0% edges, 71.9% strength ratio, modularity = 0.073 
#> 
#> Metrics at optimal point:
#>   n_edges: 9.000
#>   mean_strength: 4.324
#>   strength_ratio: 0.719
#>   modularity: 0.073
#>   n_components: 1.000
print(optimal_mod)
#> Optimal Cut-off Analysis
#> ========================
#> Optimal cut-off value: 1.200 
#> Criterion used: modularity 
#> Explanation: Maximum modularity (0.221): 4 edges, 1 components 
#> 
#> Metrics at optimal point:
#>   n_edges: 4.000
#>   mean_strength: 2.962
#>   strength_ratio: 0.717
#>   modularity: 0.221
#>   n_components: 1.000

# Extract just the cut-off values for comparison
cat("Elbow method suggests:", round(optimal_elbow$optimal_cutoff, 3), "\n")
#> Elbow method suggests: 1.382 
cat("Balance method suggests:", round(optimal_balance$optimal_cutoff, 3), "\n")
#> Balance method suggests: 0.219 
cat("Modularity method suggests:", round(optimal_mod$optimal_cutoff, 3), "\n")
#> Modularity method suggests: 1.2 

# 2. Visualize sensitivity curves to understand criterion choices
sensitivity <- optimal_elbow$sensitivity_analysis

if (require(ggplot2, quietly = TRUE)) {
  library(ggplot2)

  # Plot strength ratio (elbow criterion looks for inflection point here)
  p1 <- ggplot(sensitivity, aes(x = cutoff, y = strength_ratio)) +
    geom_line() +
    geom_vline(xintercept = optimal_elbow$optimal_cutoff,
               linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
    labs(title = "Elbow Point in Strength Ratio",
         x = "Cut-off", y = "Strength Ratio") +
    theme_minimal()
  print(p1)

  # Plot modularity (modularity criterion maximizes this)
  p2 <- ggplot(sensitivity, aes(x = cutoff, y = modularity)) +
    geom_line() +
    geom_vline(xintercept = optimal_mod$optimal_cutoff,
               linetype = "dashed", color = "blue") +
    labs(title = "Modularity Across Cut-offs",
         x = "Cut-off", y = "Modularity") +
    theme_minimal()
  print(p2)
}



# 3. Practical workflow: Find optimal cut-off and run MONECA
optimal <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "balance", verbose = FALSE)

# Use the optimal cut-off in MONECA clustering
seg <- moneca(data, cut.off = optimal$optimal_cutoff, segment.levels = 3)

# 4. Compare network properties across criteria
criteria <- c("elbow", "balance", "modularity", "information")
results <- lapply(criteria, function(crit) {
  opt <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = crit, verbose = FALSE)
  data.frame(
    criterion = crit,
    cutoff = opt$optimal_cutoff,
    n_edges = opt$metrics$n_edges,
    modularity = opt$metrics$modularity,
    n_components = opt$metrics$n_components
  )
})
comparison <- do.call(rbind, results)
print(comparison)
#>     criterion    cutoff n_edges modularity n_components

#> 2     balance 0.2191032       9 0.07286871            1
#> 3  modularity 1.1999850       4 0.22056911            1
#> 4 information 1.8902351       2 0.00000000            3

# 5. Stability analysis (more computationally intensive)
# \donttest{
optimal_stable <- find_optimal_cutoff(data, criterion = "stability",
                                      n_bootstrap = 50, verbose = TRUE)
